meeting_annotations.speaker: Annika Barber
meeting_annotations.transcript: Let's not do that.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Judith Elsen
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yes, we I guess we'd have to said something like this up and maybe one of the Scandinavian countries where they are really good about reporting and uh collecting and curating information and

meeting_annotations.speaker: Annika Barber
meeting_annotations.transcript: And where people have enough healthcare that they're not going to get nixed for pre-existing conditions, which I think was a huge barrier for that type of thing in the US.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Judith Elsen
meeting_annotations.transcript: And where people don't think it's an invasion of their privacy.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Annika Barber
meeting_annotations.transcript: I mean, I think it is an invasion of our privacy, but I wouldn't mind if I could still get healthcare.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Judith Elsen
meeting_annotations.transcript: Right. Yeah.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Annika Barber
meeting_annotations.transcript: But yeah, I mean a UK biobank style, I mean, I don't know, maybe it's something the UK biobank would consider adding at some point.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Faranak Fattahi
meeting_annotations.transcript: Sure, yeah.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Annika Barber
meeting_annotations.transcript: I know that it's definitely like an evolving thing, they have different different participant groups with different um levels of data that they're collecting.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Annika Barber
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, because I saw a study recently because I'm in sleep fields where they had like 90,000 people that wore accelerometers for two weeks and they looked at their sleep patterns and I mean now obviously it wasn't the whole UK biobank, but somewhere they found 90,000 people to wear a Fitbit for two weeks.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Faranak Fattahi
meeting_annotations.transcript: Right, I think they do have some like uh bio bio specimen repository suit for a fraction of the UK biobank participants, but I don't know if they, you know, have plans to then add genomics of the microbiome or transcriptomics of the microbiome to that as well.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Annika Barber
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, it's probably one of those things where like if somebody had the funding for it, they could add it.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Annika Barber
meeting_annotations.transcript: It's all of these things take time and money and people, people being the most expensive and then data storage after that.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Faranak Fattahi
meeting_annotations.transcript: That's right.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Annika Barber
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think the other problem too is is knowing, you know, from the mental health side of things is what is one disease?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Annika Barber
meeting_annotations.transcript: I mean, that's something the mental health field still hasn't figured out. Like is depression one thing? Is, you know, is schizophrenia one thing? Is bipolar disorder one thing?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Annika Barber
meeting_annotations.transcript: You know, when we can't define the disease state in humans and it's only defined descriptively, it's hard to correlate, you know, it's easy to say like you have stage one melanoma, like that's a thing and we can define it and we can be sure that everything we correlate with that thing is being correlated with the same disease.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Annika Barber
meeting_annotations.transcript: But I think for a lot of psychiatric disorders or even things like autism spectrum disorders.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Annika Barber
meeting_annotations.transcript: We can't say for sure that something is one disease.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Annika Barber
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, which is not a problem you can solve with the microbiome.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Judith Elsen
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I think that's compounded because people have um at least in some some genetic studies that suggest um a significant overlap of some of the some of the alleles, some of the mutations that are involved in some of these diseases, but then particular alleles of particular genes um are tend to be more linked with some versus others of of these uh uh mental health diseases.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Annika Barber
meeting_annotations.transcript: Right, we're making categorical bins out of a continuous variable.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Judith Elsen
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah. Yeah.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Judith Elsen
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Annika Barber
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I mean, I think that's, you know, just another big problem.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Faranak Fattahi
meeting_annotations.transcript: Mhm.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Annika Barber
meeting_annotations.transcript: In mental health research broadly.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Judith Elsen
meeting_annotations.transcript: Well, and timing is an issue too because if somebody doesn't display symptoms, whatever, however we're going to uh recognize those, then we don't we don't know and probably wouldn't do research on them and yet maybe that's the the most appropriate time to to to start thinking about interventions.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Rachel Saylor (Oberlin College)
meeting_annotations.transcript: And that's the self-reporting thing, you know, because it's still.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Linnea Freeman- Furman University
meeting_annotations.transcript: That just made me think too that if it could be boiled down, which likely no, but um to some sort of signature within the microbiome that could be predictive of a mental health disorder because a lot of these that we are talking about like I said before are not early childhood.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Linnea Freeman- Furman University
meeting_annotations.transcript: I mean some are, but um but are they just not presenting symptoms until later? So if if the data moved towards like all of these collective um really large studies and found some sort of signature of a group of bacteria or a change in diversity or whatever it might be.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Linnea Freeman- Furman University
meeting_annotations.transcript: I just wonder if that could be used as a biomarker and I see a lot of issues with that too, but um.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Linnea Freeman- Furman University
meeting_annotations.transcript: Could that be predictive of developing PTSD or something? I mean that's the kind of thing you think of like DOD grant or something like are these people going to go into a situation and be more vulnerable to experiencing PTSD.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Rachel Saylor (Oberlin College)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, and I think even beyond that, this is tangentially related. Like having a biomarker that is specific or a host, I guess, of biomarkers that are specific for depression, anxiety, whatever.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Rachel Saylor (Oberlin College)
meeting_annotations.transcript: And then being able to.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Rachel Saylor (Oberlin College)
meeting_annotations.transcript: Say, okay, if you have these three biomarkers, then you should take this antidepressant, whereas if you have these, you know, seven biomarkers, this is going to work better for you.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Rachel Saylor (Oberlin College)
meeting_annotations.transcript: That would be really, really powerful.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Faranak Fattahi
meeting_annotations.transcript: So precision medicine on top of.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Faranak Fattahi
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah.

meeting_annotations.transcript: I'm busy starting to make notes, that's why I'm quiet.
